CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 2, 1960, pg. 3 reads: "Picket Line Here Protests Dixie Bias - While a curious throng of onlookers, including some self-styled leaders of the fight for civil rights, watched with interest, approximately 80 men, women and youths threw an effective picket line around the downtown Woolworth store here, in protest against the chain company's acquiescence to the insulting segregation policy at its lunch counters in South...Lower left photo, left to right, front-line fighters in the battle for civil rights, who walked the hour long march, were militant "Mal" Goode of The Courier, Atty. Byrd Brown, scrappy civic leader who believes that the Constitution of the United States should apply to ALL citizens, and Boyd L. Wilson, international representative of the United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO, and veteran civil rights campaigner...Among those unafraid to be counted in the picket line were Atty. Henry R. Smith, state president of the NAACP; Dr. Hugh Cleland, Pitt history professor; Peter D. Hammond, Pitt anthropology professor; the Revs. J.B. Cayce, Ebenezer Baptist Church; Churchill Carter, Park Place AME, Homestead; R. H. Reid, Payne Chapel AME, Duquesne, and J.G. Jarris, Bethel AME, Pittsburgh; Mrs. Marion B. Jordon, Mrs. Paul Knitt, James O. Dougan, Matthew Moore, Regis Bobonis, and The Courier's George E. Barbour and Frank E. Bolden - Harris Photos
TitMainTitle: Protestors, including Henry Smith, Mal Goode, Byrd Brown, and Boyd L. Wilson holding sign reading "The Battle for Civil Rights is not only a Negro Problem, but the Concern of all Good Americans," outside of Woolworth's, Smithfield Street and Sixth Avenue, Downtown
CatSubject_tab: Picketing--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.Men--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.Department stores--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.Goode, Mal, 1908-1995.Brown, Byrd, 1929-Wilson, Boyd L.Bolden, Frank, 1914-2003.
